introduction.p: When two resistors are connected end-to-end such that the same current must flow through both, then we say that the resistors are conected in series as shown in .

figure.caption: Two resitors in series in a circuit if same current passes through them both.

subsection.title: Current and Voltages in Series
subsection.p:
In , the resitors in series are connected to a voltage source such that we set up a potential differece across the two resistors.
\phi_a - \phi_b = V.
But since we do not know the potential drop across either of the two resitors, we cannot apply Ohm's law to either resitor to find the current through them. If we apply Ohm's law to each of the two resitors we will get the following equations with unknown \phi_c as well as I.
\phi_a - \phi_c \amp = I R_1.
\phi_c - \phi_b \amp = I R_2.
We can think of finding I as an algebra problem for these two equations. You can eliminate \phi_c by adding the two equations and solve for I.
I = \dfrac{V}{R_1 + R_2}.
Using this in the two equations above, we can immediately find the voltage drops across each resitor.
\Delta\phi_1 \amp = \phi_a - \phi_c = V \dfrac{ R_1 }{R_1 + R_2}.
\Delta\phi_2 \amp =\phi_c - \phi_b = V \dfrac{ R_2 }{R_1 + R_2}.
From these you can see that total voltage drop V has been proportionaltely shared by the two resistors in series. We say that resitors in series divide-up the total voltage acoss them in proportion of their own resitance - the resitor with higher resitance has the higher proportion of voltage across it.
An open circuit with no connection, say between b and c in will have R_2=\infty, and all voltage will drop across such an open line. We call such places in a circuit to be open circuit.

subsection.title: Equivalent Resistance of Resitors in Series
subsection.p:
It is instructive to think of resistors in series conceptually, as well, which we do next. To find the common current I through resistors in series, we will combine them into one resistor, to which we can apply Ohm's law. For instance, if resistor R_1 is a 5\text{-m} copper wire and R_2 is a 3\text{-m} copper wire, then we can replace them with 5+3=8\text{-m} wire of same thickness. That means, the net resitance of two resistors in series is
R_\text{series} = R_1 + R_2.
These arguments for two resitors in series can be easily extend to the case of N resistors in series, giving us
R_\text{series} = R_1 + R_2 + \cdots + R_N.

We say that between points a and b, in the two resistors present an equivalent resistance, R_\text{equiv},
R_\text{equiv} = R_\text{series} = R_1 + R_2.
We may think of an equivalent circuit that has only one resitor, with resistance R_\text{equiv} rather than two resistors of the original circuit, without affecting the original circuit outside of points a and b, as indicated in .

Now, we can apply Ohm's law for this equivalent resistor to obtain current I as
I = \dfrac{\Delta \phi}{R_\text{equiv}} = \dfrac{\phi_a - \phi_b}{R_1 + R_2} = \dfrac{V}{R_1 + R_2},
where I have replaced \phi_a-\phi_b by V as we noted in Eq. .

figure.caption: Two resitors in series in a circuit can be replaced by an equivalent resistor without affecting circuit outside of points a and b.

subsection.title: Potential Drops Across Each Resistor in Series
subsection.p:
Now, we can use Ohm's law on each of the resistor, as in Eqs. and , to find potential drops across each.
\Delta\phi_1 = \phi_a - \phi_c \amp = \dfrac{R_1}{R_1 + R_2}\, V,
\Delta\phi_2 = \phi_c - \phi_b \amp = \dfrac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}\, V.

sidebyside.p:
An important conceptual lesson to note here is that total potential drop across the two resistors, \Delta\phi = \phi_a - \phi_b\equiv V, is actually a sum of the potential drops \Delta\phi_1 = \phi_a - \phi_c\equiv V_1 and \Delta\phi_2 = \phi_c - \phi_b\equiv V_2 across the two resitors in series.
V = V_1 + V_2.

subsection.p: We say that original voltage across the two has been divided up between the two resitors. We say that resitors in series is a volatage-divider circuit! Eqs. and tell us that the total voltage drop V has been proportionaltely shared by the two resistors in series. We say that resitors in series divide-up the total voltage acoss them in proportion of their own resitance - the resitor with higher resitance has the higher proportion of voltage across it.

exercise.title: Current, Voltage, and Power in Resistors in Series Circuit

statement.p: The circuit in shows two resitors in series with a voltage source.

p.p: (c) Find power dissipated in each resistor.

statement.p: (d) How much energy is delivered to the circuit by the voltage source in 10\text{ minutes}.

answer.p: (a) 0.4\text{ A}, (b) 4\text{ V}, 8\text{ V}, (c) 1.6\text{ W} , 3.2\text{ W} , (d) 2,880\text{ J} .

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Since the resitors are in series, same current I flows through both resitors and encounters a net resistance R_1 + R_2.
I \amp = \dfrac{V}{R_1 + R_2} = \dfrac{12\ \text{V}} {10\ \Omega + 20\ \Omega} = 0.4\text{ A}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Same current I flows through both resitors. Applying Ohm's law on each resitor will give us the potential drops across each of the resitors.
V_1 \amp = I_1R_1 = IR_1 = 0.4\text{ A} \times 10\ \Omega = 4\text{ V}, V_2 \amp = I_2R_2 = IR_2 = 0.4\text{ A} \times 20\ \Omega = 8\text{ V}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Power dissipated in a resitor equals IV for that resistor.
P_1 \amp = I_1 V_1 = I V_1 = 0.4\text{ A} \times 4\text{ V} = 1.6\text{ W}. P_2 \amp = I_2 V_2 = I V_1 = 0.4\text{ A} \times 8\text{ V} = 3.2\text{ W}.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
(d) Energy conservation means the energy lost to the resitors must be suplied by the voltage source. Therefore, the net power of the source must be
P_\text{source} = P_1 + P_2 = 4.8\text{ W}.
Therefore energy supplied in 10\text{ minutes} will be
E = P_\text{source}\Delta t = 4.8\text{ W} \times 600\text{ s} = 2,880\text{ J}.

example.title: Dependence of the Terminal Voltage of Battery on the Load

statement.p: Every battery has an internal resistance. As a result voltage measured at the terminals is not equal to the EMF of the battery. While EMF of the battery is determined by the chemical potential of the chemicals involved, the potential difference, i.e., the voltage across terminals, depends on the resistance of the load connected across the terminals as we will show in the solution here.

If you want to explore the issue yourself, try finding a formula for the potential drop across the terminals in the following figure, which has a battery with EMF V and internal resistance R_i connected to a load of resistance R_L. Then, explore V_T as a function of R_L. What happens when R_L \gt\gt R_i?

hint.p: R_i and R_L are in series.

solution.p:
From the circuit, we see that R_L and R_i are in series. We also see that the terminal voltage is just the potential drop across the load R_L. Therefore,
V_T = \phi_b - \phi_c = I R_L = \dfrac{R_L}{R_L + R_i}\, V.
Therefore, the voltage across the terminals of a battery depends upon whatever you connect across its terminals. However, if R_i \lt \lt R_L, then V_t can be approximately independent of the load.
V_T = \dfrac{R_L}{R_L + R_i}\, V \approx V\text{ if }R_i=0\text { or } R_i \lt\lt R_L.
This can be illustrated for a voltaic cell of EMF 1.5 volts and internal resistance 1\ \Omega. With a 1000\text{-} \Omega resistor load, the terminal voltage will be approximately 1.5 volts, but with a 0.5\text{-}\Omega load resistor, the voltage across the same terminals will be only 0.5 volt!
